title: Project title
text:
Introduction and data

The data is from the American National Election Studies

American National Election Studies. 2021. ANES 2020 Time Series Study Full Release [dataset and documentation]. July 19, 2021 version. www.electionstudies.org

The data was gathered via interviews with 8,280 individuals pre-election and 7,449 individuals post-election. The data was gathered in a variety of interview formats, including web only, mixed web (web and phone), and mixed video (video, web, and phone).
We have written out a list of some key variables from the data. In parenthesis by each variable, we have written the code used in the data set to denote the variable:

Categorical Variables:

Sex (V201600), Sexual orientation (V201601), race/ethnicity (V201549x)
Voted in-person or by mail/absentee (V202117)
Party of US House Vote (V202111x), party of US Presidential vote (V202110x), party of Senate vote (V202112x), party of governor vote (V202113x)

Quantitative Variables:

Respondents were asked to give a thermometer rating between 0-100 about how they felt about certain groups after the election. Some thermometer ratings of note are those given to transgender people (V202172), gay men and lesbians (V202166), big business (V202163), police (V202171), scientists (V202173), journalists (V202175), Black Lives Matter (V202174), NRA (V202178), socialists (V202179), and rural Americans (V202184)
Data on the income level of the respondent has been redacted by ANES.

title: Project title
text:
Research question

With this dataset, there is a wide variety of possible research questions. Some possible research questions include:

How is whether an individual voted by mail/absentee and their sex (categorical) associated with their “thermometer” rating of the NRA (quantitative)?
How is the party of an individual’s Presidential vote and their race (categorical) associated with their “thermometer” rating of Black Lives Matter (quantitative)?

For the first research topic, our hypothesis is that males who did not vote by mail are more likely to have a higher “thermometer” rating for the NRA. Conversely, we expect women who did vote by mail to have lower “thermometer” ratings for the NRA.
For the second research topic, our hypothesis is that Republican Caucasians are more likely to have a lower “thermometer” rating for BLM while Democratic people of color are more likely to have a higher “thermometer” rating for BLM.

title: Project title
text:
Literature

Thompson, D. M., Wu, J. A., Yoder, J., & Hall, A. B. (2020). Universal vote-by-mail has no impact on partisan turnout or vote share. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 117(25), 14052–14056. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2007249117
The study analyzes states that implemented universal vote-by-mail, between 1996 and 2018. The study’s analysis counters a popular narrative in the media that voting my mail favors Democrats. The study found that universal vote-by-mail does not impact either political party’s share of turnout. Moreover, the study concluded that universal vote-by-mail did not increase the vote share of either party. Finally, the study found that universal vote-by-mail only caused modest increases in overall average turnout rates.
This study finds that universal voting by mail did not have partisan impacts in states that implemented it between 1996 and 2018. Our research will analyze whether voting by mail did have a partisan impact in the 2020 election - when voting by mail was implemented in the US at a larger scale than ever before because of COVID (by looking at highly-partisan thermometer ratings such as the NRA).

title: Project title
text:
Introduction and data

Identify the source of the data.

United States Environmental Protection Agency
https://www.epa.gov/outdoor-air-quality-data/download-daily-data

State when and how it was originally collected (by the original data curator, not necessarily how you found the data).

The data was collected from air quality monitors from three sites in Alabama that reported the data to the EPA.

Write a brief description of the observations.

The data set has summary statistics for the atmospheric Carbon Monoxide by date (every day in the year) and monitor location.

title: Project title
text:
Research question

A well-formulated research question. (You may include more than one research question if you want to receive feedback on different ideas for your project. However, one per data set is required.)

How are Daily Max 8-hour CO Concentration and daily AQI (Air Quality Index) value (quantitative) associated with the month of the year (categorical)?

A description of the research topic along with a concise statement of your hypotheses on this topic.

We hypothesize that CO Concentration and AQI will be lowest during December and January (lower AQI = better air quality).

Identify the types of variables in your research question. Categorical? Quantitative?

Defined above

title: Project title
text:
Literature

Chen, Y., Ma, Q., Lin, W., Xu, X., Yao, J., & Gao, W. (2020). Measurement report: Long-term variations in carbon monoxide at a background station in China’s Yangtze River Delta Region. Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics, 20(24), 15969–15982. https://doi.org/10.5194/acp-20-15969-2020
This paper analyzed Carbon Monoxide levels in China’s Yangtze River Delta region between 2007 and 2017. The paper found that CO levels have dropped in the Yangtze River Delta region from 0.66 ± 0.03 ppm in 2006-2009 to 0.52 ± 0.01 ppm in 2016-2017. Moreover, the paper found that CO levels were highest in the winter (0.69 ± 0.08 ppm) and lowest in the summer (0.54 ± 0.06 ppm).
Our research question adds to this paper by providing insight into CO atmospheric levels in Alabama to see how they compare to China. Perhaps, seasonal CO trends in Alabama will not mirror the observations made in the Yangtze River Delta.

title: Project title
text:
Introduction and data

Identify the source of the data.
LBA-ECO LC-09 Soil Composition and Structure in the Brazilian Amazon: 1992 -1995. https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/lba-eco-lc-09-soil-composition-and-structure-in-the-brazilian-amazon-1992-1995
State when and how it was originally collected (by the original data curator, not necessarily how you found the data).
November 12, 2007.
Write a brief description of the observations.
Each observation describes, for a specific site (latitude, longitude) in a chosen city, data such as carbon emissions per ha, the number of burns in the area, and the depth of the area for the Brazilian Amazon.

title: Project title
text:
Research question

A well-formulated research question. (You may include more than one research question if you want to receive feedback on different ideas for your project. However, one per data set is required.)
1) What is the relationship between deforestation in the Amazon and carbon emissions?
2) What is the relationship between carbon emissions in the Amazon and the number of burns?
A description of the research topic along with a concise statement of your hypotheses on this topic.
1) The Brazilian Amazon has been suffering from illegal mining and deforestation, data which have been increasing in the past few decades (Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics - IBGE, 2021). Based on the fact that affects the greatest rainforest in the world, the proposal of the analysis of this data is to check how this deforestation and increase in carbon emission in the Amazon area affects the area, population, and mainly the vegetation.
Identify the types of variables in your research question. Categorical? Quantitative?

title: Project title
text:
Literature

Find one published credible article on the topic you are interested in researching.
1) Gondim, M. L. C., & Ferreira, J. (2012). O arco de desflorestamento na Amazônia: da pecuária à soja. Ambiente & Sociedade, 15(2), 23-40. https://doi.org/10.1590/S1414-753X2012000200002
2) Marengo, J. A., & Nobre, C. A. (2001). Aquecimento global e mudança climática na Amazônia: Retroalimentação clima-vegetação e impactos nos recursos hídricos. Estudos avançados, 15(43), 37-52. https://doi.org/10.1590/S0103-40142001000300004
Provide a one-paragraph summary of the article.
1st article: Brazil is the largest exporter and second largest producer of soybeans in the world. However, the increase in production has been directly associated to the deforestation of the Amazon Rainforest. This culture began in the South and moved toward the central region of the country, spreading gradually to its northern part. This growth was mainly based on monoculture properties controlled by large transnational corporations, and has replaced the local biome: the Amazon rainforest. Such fact has worried both public and private entities, since there has been an excessive deforestation and biodiversity loss. This study analyses the advance of soybean in the North of the Brazilian state of Mato Grosso, in the period 1984-2009, by means of satellite image interpretation. As a result, presents three maps of land use development in the area of study. It is noticed that the recent deforestation was due to the livestock activities and, afterwards, the eroded soil from the open fields and pastures were recovered with the soybean crops. In other words, in the analyzed area, soy plantations were not directly established over the deforested areas, but rather over areas previously degraded by livestock.
2nd article: It discusses the complex relationship between climate change, vegetation, and water resources in the Amazon. The authors explore how climate feedback mechanisms, such as the water and energy cycles, are affected by deforestation, land use changes, and greenhouse gas emissions, leading to changes in precipitation patterns, temperature, and vegetation cover. These changes, in turn, have significant impacts on the hydrological cycle and water resources, affecting the Amazonian ecosystem and its inhabitants. The article concludes by highlighting the urgent need for better understanding of these feedback mechanisms and the implementation of strategies to mitigate the impacts of climate change in the Amazon region.
In 1-2 sentences, explain how your research question builds on / is different than the article you have cited.
The first article cited provides insights into the relationship between deforestation and soybean cultivation in the Brazilian Amazon. The second cited article focuses on the complex relationship between climate change, vegetation, and water resources in the Amazon, while my research question focuses on the relationship between deforestation, carbon emissions, and burns in the Amazon. Thus, my research question builds on the article’s discussion of the impact of land use changes on the Amazon’s climate and vegetation by specifically examining the relationship between deforestation and carbon emissions in the region.

title: Statistical Analysis of Mail-in Voting Demographics
text:
Here is the data set from the American National Election Studies:



Here is the sourced citation:

American National Election Studies. 2021. ANES 2020 Time Series Study Full Release dataset and documentation. July 19, 2021 version. www.electionstudies.org.

This data was gathered through 8,280 interviews before the 2020 presidential election and 7,499 individuals after the election. The data composed of both pre- and post- election samples from Fresh Cross-Sectional and ANES 2016-2020 Panel, and only included U.S. eligible voters. The interview formats varied from individual to individual, including through their website, a mix of their website and phone calls, and mixed internet video. The pre-election interviews took place from August 2020 and went until Election Day, Tuesday November 3rd. Post-election interviews began shortly after and ended December 31st. We do not believe that the variability in the collection of data outlined above creates any potential ethical issues.
It is important to note that the data set presents different variables depending on whether the response was pre or post election. The pre-election survey included variables on sexual harassment and misconduct, health insurance, immigration, identity politics, media trust and misinformation, institutional legitimacy, campaigns, party images, trade tariffs and tax policy. The post-election survey includes voting experiences, attitude toward public health officials and organizations, anti-elitism, faith in experts/science, climate change opinions, gun control opinions, opioids, rural/urban living, international trade, sexual harassment and MeToo, transgender military service, social media usage, opinions on misinformation, and personal experiences.
Our research question is “How does whether an individual voted by mail/absentee and their sex alignment associate with their ‘thermometer’ rating of the NRA?”. We hypothesize that a female how voted by mail/absentee is more likely to have a”thermometer” rating that disapproves of the NRA over an male who voted in person.
Here are some of the key variables from the data. The parenthesis by each variable represents the written code used in the data set to denote the variables:

Categorical Variables:

Sex (V201600): -9. Refused, 1. Male, 2. Female
Sexual orientation (V201601): -9. Refused, -5. Interview breakoff (sufficient partial IW), 1. Heterosexual or straight, 2. Homosexual or gay (or lesbian), 3. Bisexual, 4. Something else {SPECIFY}
Race/ethnicity (V201549x): -9. Refused, -8. Don’t know, 1. White, non-Hispanic, 2. Black, non-Hispanic, 3. Hispanic, 4. Asian or Native Hawaiian/other Pacific Islander, non-Hispanic alone, 5. Native American/Alaska Native or other race, non-Hispanic alone, 6. Multiple races, non-Hispanic
Voted in-person or by mail/absentee (V202117): Here is the breakdown on what the values represent: -9. Refused, -8. Don’t know, -7. No post-election data, deleted due to incomplete interview, -6. No post-election interview, -5. Interview breakoff (sufficient partial IW), -1. Inapplicable, 1. In person, at the polling place, 2. By mail or absentee ballot
Party of US House Vote (V202111x), party of US Presidential vote (V202110x), party of Senate vote (V202112x), party of governor vote (V202113x): The categorical variables were as followed: -9. Refused, -8. Don’t Know, -1. Inapplicable, 1. Voted for Democratic candidate, 2. Voted for Republican candidate, 3. Voted for other candidate

Quantitative Variables:

Respondents were asked to give a thermometer rating between 0-100 about how they felt about certain groups after the election. Some thermometer ratings of note are those given to transgender people (V202172), gay men and lesbians (V202166), big business (V202163), police (V202171), scientists (V202173), journalists (V202175), Black Lives Matter (V202174), NRA (V202178), socialists (V202179), and rural Americans (V202184)


Literature Review:

Thompson, D. M., Wu, J. A., Yoder, J., & Hall, A. B. (2020). Universal vote-by-mail has no impact on partisan turnout or vote share. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 117(25), 14052–14056. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2007249117
The study analyzes states that implemented universal vote-by-mail, between 1996 and 2018. The study’s analysis counters a popular narrative in the media that voting my mail favors Democrats. The study found that universal vote-by-mail does not impact either political party’s share of turnout. Moreover, the study concluded that universal vote-by-mail did not increase the vote share of either party. Finally, the study found that universal vote-by-mail only caused modest increases in overall average turnout rates.
This study finds that universal voting by mail did not have partisan impacts in states that implemented it between 1996 and 2018. Our research will analyze whether voting by mail did have a partisan impact in the 2020 election - when voting by mail was implemented in the US at a larger scale than ever before because of COVID (by looking at highly-partisan thermometer ratings such as the NRA).

Here is the User Guide and Codebook for all variable information/descriptions:

https://electionstudies.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/anes_timeseries_2020_userguidecodebook_20220210.pdf

Methodology:
First, we will mutate the variable names of the variables analyzed in this report to reflect their values.



Next, we’ve calculated the mean thermometer ratings of the NRA across different sexes and voting methods.


# A tibble: 1 × 1
  NRA_Rating_Entire_Sample
                     <dbl>
1                     46.9


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Sex'. You can override using the `.groups`
argument.


# A tibble: 4 × 3
# Groups:   Sex [2]
  Sex   Voting_Method mean_NRA_Thermometer_Rating
  <chr> <chr>                               <dbl>
1 F     By Mail                              42.2
2 F     In-Person                            54.9
3 M     By Mail                              44.1
4 M     In-Person                            57.9




# A tibble: 8,280 × 3
   Thermometer_Rating   Sex Voting_Method
                <dbl> <dbl>         <dbl>
 1                 50     1            -1
 2                 50     2            -1
 3                  0     2            -1
 4                999     1            -1
 5                 70     1            -1
 6                 15     2            -1
 7                 85     2            -1
 8                 50     2            -1
 9                999     2             2
10                 50     1            -1
# … with 8,270 more rows


It is possible to see non useful values in these variables. So we will need to filter it in the next code chunk.
We plan to answer the “How is whether an individual voted by mail/absentee and their sex (categorical) associated with their ‘thermometer’ rating of the NRA (quantitative)?” research question by creating a Bar Plot to visualize the research question.


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'V201600'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.





Logistical regression: how does the NRA thermometer rating (quantitative) and one’s sex (binary) impact whether someone voted by mail (binary)?
Use the predict function to predict, based off the logistic regression, what odd of voting by mail is given a thermometer rating and a sex.





parsnip model object


Call:  stats::glm(formula = V202117 ~ V202178, family = stats::binomial, 
    data = data)

Coefficients:
(Intercept)      V202178  
    1.44864     -0.01089  

Degrees of Freedom: 312 Total (i.e. Null);  311 Residual
Null Deviance:      375.6 
Residual Deviance: 366.4    AIC: 370.4


parsnip model object

    data = data)

Coefficients:
(Intercept)      V201600  
    0.87783      0.01923  

Degrees of Freedom: 312 Total (i.e. Null);  311 Residual
Null Deviance:      375.6 
Residual Deviance: 375.6    AIC: 379.6


Results
Summary Statistics Analysis:
From the point-estimates of the average sample thermometer ratings for the NRA, it seems like men and voting in person are both positively associated with NRA approval. Compared the entire sample average rating of 48.6, men had an average rating of 50.5, individuals who voted in-person had an average rating of 55.8, and men who voted in person had an average rating of 57.9. Conversely, women assigned the NRA an average rating of 46.9, individuals who voted by mail assigned a rating of 43.5, and women who voted by mail had an average rating of 42.2.
Logarithmic Regressions Analysis:
The logarithmic regression models demonstrates a similar result to the summary statistic analysis. For example, in the first model where we calculate the percent change that an individual voted in person (1) vs voting by mail (2), we see a negative correlation of \(log(p/1-p) = 1.44864 * -0.01089 * ThermometerRating\). This clearly demonstrate the negative correlation, where for every one point increase in the approval of the NRA, there is a decrease in the likelihood that an individuals voted in person (it gets closer to 1 from 2).
